articles.title: Afghan Women’s Return to Football a Human Rights Victory
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image

When the former Afghan Women's National Football Team, now known as Afghan Women United, took the field this week in Morocco for their first games in four years, they didn't just play a match; they returned from exile, from dispossession, and from a system that sought to erase them.Their return to compete after the Taliban banned all sports for women and girls is a true victory for human rights. Even before the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan in August 2021, Afghan women athletes faced death threats for representing their country. But once back in power, the Taliban systematically shut all women and girls out of sports. They shuttered training centers and banned competitions. Women athletes had to destroy evidence of their athletic lives, burying uniforms and trophies. For many, sports had been their pathway to leadership, education, employment, dignity, and joy.The players had to flee the country and make new lives for themselves abroad as refugees. They rebuilt their team, while shouldering the dreams of their former teammates in Afghanistan suffering under the Taliban’s repression.  The Sport & Rights Alliance and Human Rights Watch reported how FIFA’s nonrecognition of the Afghan women’s team effectively exported the Taliban’s repressive policies abroad and denied Afghan women athletes their right to compete, even outside Afghanistan. But after four years of seeking official recognition, the players’ determination has forced FIFA to allow the team to compete.“Playing for my country is one of the ways I can stand up for the girls back in Afghanistan,” said Fatima Foladi, who played on Afghanistan’s Under-15 and Under-19 national teams. “My dream is to be reunited with my teammates from all over the world, to play with them again and bring back the football dreams we had when we lived back home.”FIFA has not yet formally recognized the Afghan players as the women’s national team, and they should do so. FIFA and other sport federations including the International Cricket Council need to stand with Afghan women athletes, rather than those who seek to exclude them from sports.To see the team rebuilt and competing again gives hope for future generations of Afghan women and girls that they too can reclaim their rights, not only in sports but in all aspects of their lives.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Players of Afghan Women's United football team receive support from Tunisian players after the FIFA Unites: Women's Series 2025 on October 29 in Casablanca, Morocco. © 2025 Francois Nel - FIFA/FIFA via Getty Images

When the former Afghan Women's National Football Team, now known as Afghan Women United, took the field this week in Morocco for their first games in four years, they didn't just play a match; they returned from exile, from dispossession, and from a system that sought to erase them.

Their return to compete after the Taliban banned all sports for women and girls is a true victory for human rights.

Even before the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan in August 2021, Afghan women athletes faced death threats for representing their country. But once back in power, the Taliban systematically shut all women and girls out of sports. They shuttered training centers and banned competitions. Women athletes had to destroy evidence of their athletic lives, burying uniforms and trophies. For many, sports had been their pathway to leadership, education, employment, dignity, and joy.

The players had to flee the country and make new lives for themselves abroad as refugees. They rebuilt their team, while shouldering the dreams of their former teammates in Afghanistan suffering under the Taliban’s repression.

The Sport & Rights Alliance and Human Rights Watch reported how FIFA’s nonrecognition of the Afghan women’s team effectively exported the Taliban’s repressive policies abroad and denied Afghan women athletes their right to compete, even outside Afghanistan.

But after four years of seeking official recognition, the players’ determination has forced FIFA to allow the team to compete.

“Playing for my country is one of the ways I can stand up for the girls back in Afghanistan,” said Fatima Foladi, who played on Afghanistan’s Under-15 and Under-19 national teams. “My dream is to be reunited with my teammates from all over the world, to play with them again and bring back the football dreams we had when we lived back home.”

FIFA has not yet formally recognized the Afghan players as the women’s national team, and they should do so. FIFA and other sport federations including the International Cricket Council need to stand with Afghan women athletes, rather than those who seek to exclude them from sports.

To see the team rebuilt and competing again gives hope for future generations of Afghan women and girls that they too can reclaim their rights, not only in sports but in all aspects of their lives.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant human rights victory where Afghan women athletes, previously banned and forced into exile by the Taliban, have rebuilt their national football team and returned to international competition. This event symbolizes resilience, empowerment, and hope for Afghan women and girls, with broad societal implications beyond sports. The story provides detailed context on the repression faced, the struggle for recognition, and the positive impact of their return.
articles.personality_title: Afghan Women’s Football Team Returns to International Play After Four Years
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – After the Taliban took control of Afghanistan in August 2021, they banned all sports for women and girls. Before that, female athletes already faced serious threats. Many women had to leave the country and give up their sports careers.

**What happened** – This week, the Afghan Women United football team played their first games in four years at a tournament in Morocco. The team is made up of former members of Afghanistan’s national women’s football team who fled the country. They rebuilt their team abroad and have now been allowed by FIFA, the world football organization, to compete again.

**Impact** – This return is important because it shows that Afghan women can stand up and continue their sports dreams despite the Taliban’s restrictions. Playing internationally also gives these athletes a way to support girls still living in Afghanistan who cannot play sports. It challenges the Taliban’s attempt to erase women’s participation in sports.

**What’s next step** – FIFA has not yet officially recognized Afghan Women United as Afghanistan’s national team. Many believe FIFA and other sports groups should do so to fully support these athletes. The team’s return could encourage more Afghan women and girls to reclaim their rights, not just in sports but in other parts of life.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After years of exile and bans, Afghan women football players have returned to international competition, symbolizing resilience and hope for future generations.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’équipe féminine de football afghane revient en compétition internationale après quatre ans

**Contexte** – Après la prise de pouvoir des Talibans en Afghanistan en août 2021, tous les sports pour les femmes et les filles ont été interdits. Avant cela, les sportives faisaient déjà face à de graves menaces. Beaucoup ont dû quitter le pays et abandonner leur carrière sportive.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Cette semaine, l’équipe Afghan Women United a joué ses premiers matchs en quatre ans lors d’un tournoi au Maroc. Cette équipe est composée d’anciennes joueuses de l’équipe nationale féminine afghane qui ont fui le pays. Elles ont reconstruit leur équipe à l’étranger et ont maintenant été autorisées par la FIFA, l’organisation mondiale du football, à participer à nouveau.

**Impact** – Ce retour est important car il montre que les femmes afghanes peuvent poursuivre leurs rêves sportifs malgré les interdictions des Talibans. Jouer à l’international donne aussi à ces athlètes un moyen de soutenir les filles qui vivent encore en Afghanistan et ne peuvent pas faire de sport. Cela défie la volonté des Talibans d’effacer la participation des femmes dans le sport.

**Prochaine étape** – La FIFA n’a pas encore officiellement reconnu Afghan Women United comme l’équipe nationale d’Afghanistan. Beaucoup pensent que la FIFA et d’autres organisations sportives devraient le faire pour soutenir pleinement ces athlètes. articles.title: Caribbean nations receive life-saving support following devastation of Hurricane Melissa
articles.summary: As the Caribbean reels from the devastating impact of Hurricane Melissa, UN humanitarian agencies are stepping up efforts to bring relief to thousands of affected people.
articles.content:
Torrential rain, storm surges, and landslides caused by the hurricane have left a trail of destruction across the region, with homes flattened, roads and bridges washed away, and vast areas still without power or Internet access and other telecommunications.

The UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA) said that aid supplies are on the way and that emergency teams are supporting government responses in Jamaica, Cuba and Haiti.

Tweet URL

Jamaica, food support

In Jamaica, the World Food Programme (WFP) has assisted the Government with logistics, communications, and cash-based support, delivering 5,000 food kits — enough to feed 15,000 people for a week.

The situation in the southern part of the country remains “apocalyptic”, with homes submerged, roads blocked, and people sleeping in the streets, said Brian Bogart, WFP Country Director.

Despite this, Mr Bogart noted that prior preparedness efforts had helped speed up the response but emphasised that Jamaica’s resilience “must now be supported.”

The UN is deploying emergency medical teams, supporting water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) efforts, providing psychological care, and assisting with disease surveillance.

The Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) is preparing to send 5.5 tons of humanitarian aid, including health and trauma kits, medical backpacks, tents, water supplies, mosquito nets, and personal protective equipment.

More than 284,000 Jamaican children are now in urgent need of support in the areas of health, education, nutrition, and protection, said the local UN child agency (UNICEF) team.

“Yesterday, we were on our way to Black River in St Elizabeth, one of the hardest hit areas but the roads were blocked with fallen trees and power lines, and this prevented us from reaching the most affected communities,” said the top UNICEF official on the island, Olga Isaza.

The agency is responding swiftly to support the Government and other partners to assess the needs and deliver pre-positioned supplies including food, clean water, medicines, and emergency hygiene kits. Additional humanitarian aid is ready to be airlifted.

Cuba, health assistance

Meanwhile, from its Regional Strategic Stockpile in Panama, PAHO has dispatched 2.6 tons of humanitarian aid to Cuba.

The shipment includes emergency kits with medicines, medical, and surgical supplies sufficient to care for 5,000 people for three months. It also includes chlorine tablets to treat millions of litres of water, along with essential medical and shelter supplies.

UN Spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric said that in eastern Cuba, “preliminary assessments indicate severe damage across Santiago, Holguín, Granma, and Guantánamo, including to homes, roads, and health facilities,” adding that “hundreds of communities remain isolated, and access continues to be hampered by damaged road, rail, and air transport infrastructure.”

Once ground communications are restored, supplies will be sent to the most affected areas of eastern Cuba.

Mr Dujarric said that the UN “along with our partners are supporting national authorities with assessments and early recovery plans.”

UN News interviewed Dennis Zulu, the UN’s Resident coordinator and most senior official in Jamaica, about the immediate priorities on the ground:
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article reports on significant humanitarian aid efforts by UN agencies providing life-saving support to thousands affected by Hurricane Melissa in multiple Caribbean nations. The impact is broad, involving large populations in Jamaica, Cuba, and Haiti, and the story contains detailed context about the aid delivered and ongoing response efforts. This represents a meaningful positive real-world impact on vulnerable communities recovering from a natural disaster.
articles.personality_title: UN agencies deliver vital aid to Caribbean after Hurricane Melissa
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Hurricane Melissa caused heavy rain, floods, and landslides in the Caribbean, damaging homes, roads, and communication systems in Jamaica, Cuba, and Haiti.

**What happened** – The United Nations (UN) humanitarian agencies quickly responded by sending food, medical supplies, and emergency teams. In Jamaica, the World Food Programme delivered 5,000 food kits to help 15,000 people for a week. The Pan American Health Organization sent health and trauma kits to Cuba. UNICEF is working to support children affected by the disaster.

**Impact** – The aid is helping thousands of people survive despite the severe damage. For example, in Jamaica, many homes are flooded and roads blocked, but food and medical help are reaching those in need. The support also includes clean water, hygiene supplies, and psychological care, which are important for health and safety.

**What's next step** – UN teams will continue assessing damage and delivering supplies as roads and communications improve. They will also help local governments plan recovery efforts to rebuild communities and restore services.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN’s prompt aid is providing crucial support to thousands of Caribbean residents struggling to recover from Hurricane Melissa’s destruction.

articles.summary: 'Chat control', the controversial system for detecting images of child abuse, is being removed from a European legislative proposal on the protection of minors online. This has been reported by the Danish Minister of Justice, writes Euractiv.
articles.content:
‘Chat control’, the controversial system for detecting images of child abuse, is being removed from a European legislative proposal on the protection of minors online. This has been reported by the Danish Minister of Justice, writes Euractiv.

The European Commission launched a legislative proposal in 2022 to combat the spread of child abuse images on the internet. In particular, the requirement for online platforms and messaging services to use technology that can scan users’ private messages for child abuse images, even on encrypted messaging services like Signal or WhatsApp, has caused much controversy in recent years.

There is significant resistance from the European Parliament, and several member states, including Germany, are speaking about a “disproportionate” infringement on privacy.

Belgium has not yet taken a position on ‘chat control’, but earlier this month, during a debate in the Chamber, it became clear that no party is in favor.

After years of difficult discussions, Denmark, currently holding the presidency of the EU Council, has now decided to remove the controversial measure from the text, hoping to reach an agreement. Screening for child abuse images would thus remain voluntary, reports Euractiv. Denmark has made the protection of minors on the internet one of the key points of its presidency.

Moreover, time is running out to approve new legislation. A transitional arrangement, whereby internet platforms voluntarily screen for the distribution of child sexual abuse material, expires in April next year.
articles.reasoning: The removal of the controversial 'chat control' system from EU legislation represents a significant decision balancing child protection online with privacy rights, reflecting meaningful progress in protecting minors without disproportionate privacy infringements. This impacts millions of internet users across Europe and addresses a critical human rights issue.
articles.personality_title: EU drops mandatory chat scanning to protect children while respecting privacy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union has been working on new rules to stop the spread of child abuse images online. One idea, called 'chat control,' would have made online services scan private messages, even on apps like WhatsApp or Signal, to find illegal images. This raised concerns about privacy.

**What happened** – Denmark, leading the EU Council right now, announced that 'chat control' will be removed from the proposed law. Instead, companies can choose to scan messages voluntarily. This decision comes after many EU countries and lawmakers said the scanning was too intrusive and could harm users’ privacy.

**Impact** – Removing the mandatory scanning means children will still be protected online, but people’s private messages won’t be automatically checked by technology. This respects privacy rights while keeping efforts to fight child abuse. It affects millions of internet users across Europe and shows the EU is trying to find a fair balance.

**What's next step** – The EU will continue working on ways to protect children online without forcing companies to scan all private chats. The current voluntary system for spotting abuse images will end next April, so new rules need to be agreed on soon.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU has decided to protect children online by dropping mandatory message scanning, aiming to balance safety and privacy for millions of users.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UE abandonne le contrôle obligatoire des messages pour protéger les enfants tout en respectant la vie privée
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Union européenne travaille sur de nouvelles règles pour lutter contre la diffusion d'images d'abus sexuels sur enfants en ligne. Une idée, appelée « contrôle des chats », aurait obligé les services en ligne à scanner les messages privés, même sur des applications comme WhatsApp ou Signal. Cela a suscité des inquiétudes concernant la vie privée.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le Danemark, qui dirige actuellement le Conseil de l'UE, a annoncé que le « contrôle des chats » serait retiré de la proposition de loi. À la place, les entreprises pourront choisir de scanner les messages de façon volontaire. Cette décision suit les critiques de plusieurs pays et députés européens jugeant ce contrôle trop intrusif.

**Impact** – Le retrait du scan obligatoire signifie que les enfants seront toujours protégés en ligne, mais que les messages privés ne seront pas automatiquement vérifiés par la technologie. Cela respecte les droits à la vie privée tout en continuant la lutte contre les abus. Cela concerne des millions d’utilisateurs en Europe et montre que l’UE cherche un équilibre juste.

**Prochaine étape** – L’UE va poursuivre ses efforts pour protéger les enfants en ligne sans imposer le scan systématique des messages privés. Le système volontaire actuel pour détecter les images d’abus prendra fin en avril prochain, donc de nouvelles règles doivent être adoptées rapidement.

**Phrase clé** – L’UE a choisi de protéger les enfants en ligne en abandonnant le scan obligatoire des messages, cherchant un équilibre entre sécurité et vie privée pour des millions d’utilisateurs.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE elimina el escaneo obligatorio de mensajes para proteger a los niños respetando la privacidad
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea ha estado trabajando en nuevas reglas para detener la difusión de imágenes de abuso infantil en internet. Una idea llamada 'control de chats' habría obligado a los servicios en línea a escanear mensajes privados, incluso en aplicaciones como WhatsApp o Signal. Esto preocupaba por la privacidad.

**Qué pasó** – Dinamarca, que actualmente lidera el Consejo de la UE, anunció que el 'control de chats' será eliminado de la propuesta de ley. En cambio, las empresas podrán escanear mensajes de forma voluntaria. Esta decisión llegó después de que varios países y parlamentarios europeos dijeran que el escaneo era demasiado invasivo.

**Impacto** – Quitar el escaneo obligatorio significa que los niños seguirán protegidos en línea, pero los mensajes privados no serán revisados automáticamente por tecnología. Esto respeta los derechos de privacidad mientras continúa la lucha contra el abuso. Afecta a millones de usuarios en Europa y muestra que la UE busca un equilibrio justo.

**Próximo paso** – La UE seguirá trabajando para proteger a los niños en línea sin obligar a las empresas a escanear todos los mensajes privados. El sistema voluntario actual para detectar imágenes de abuso terminará en abril próximo, por lo que deben acordarse nuevas reglas pronto.

**Frase clave** – La UE decidió proteger a los niños en línea eliminando el escaneo obligatorio de mensajes, buscando equilibrar seguridad y privacidad para millones de usuarios.

articles.title: Ukraine's invisible wounds of war: Soldiers seek solace at Greece's Mount Athos
articles.summary: Mount Athos, in northern Greece, is the beating heart of the Orthodox Christian faith and home to 2,000 monks. But for the past year, it has also become a place of refuge and pilgrimage for Ukrainian soldiers. For these men, wounded at war and suffering from deep trauma, Mount Athos's retreats offer them a respite from the front lines. The goal is to heal their trauma through faith and soothe their invisible wounds before returning to battle. Eric de Lavarène and Alexandros Kottis report.

articles.personality_title: Ukrainian soldiers find healing at Greece’s Mount Athos monastery
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Mount Athos is a mountain and monastery area in northern Greece known as an important center of Orthodox Christianity. It is home to about 2,000 monks who live a peaceful, spiritual life.

**What happened** – For the past year, Ukrainian soldiers who have been wounded or deeply affected by war have been visiting Mount Athos. They come to this quiet place to rest and recover from the emotional pain caused by fighting. The monks and the peaceful surroundings help the soldiers find comfort and strength through their faith.

**Impact** – This is important because many soldiers suffer from invisible wounds like trauma and stress, which are hard to treat. The retreats at Mount Athos offer a special kind of healing that goes beyond physical care. It helps these soldiers feel calmer and more hopeful before they return to their duties.

**What’s next step** – The soldiers will continue to visit Mount Athos for healing, and this approach might encourage other places to use spiritual care as part of helping people recover from war trauma.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Ukrainian soldiers wounded in war are finding peace and healing through faith retreats at Mount Athos, helping them cope with trauma before returning to battle.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des soldats ukrainiens trouvent la guérison au monastère du mont Athos en Grèce
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le mont Athos est une montagne et un site monastique dans le nord de la Grèce, connu comme un centre important du christianisme orthodoxe. Il abrite environ 2 000 moines qui vivent une vie paisible et spirituelle.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Depuis un an, des soldats ukrainiens blessés ou profondément affectés par la guerre visitent le mont Athos. Ils viennent dans ce lieu calme pour se reposer et se remettre de la douleur émotionnelle causée par les combats. Les moines et le cadre paisible aident les soldats à trouver du réconfort et de la force grâce à leur foi.
